latex:

\[
\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
 t & 1.9 & 2.0 & 2.1 \\
\hline
 f(t) & 6.86 & 8.00 & 9.26 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

options.label: A
options.explanation: This is the backward difference: $\frac{f(2.0)-f(1.9)}{0.1}=11.4$.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct: symmetric estimate $\frac{f(2.1)-f(1.9)}{0.2}=12.0$ best matches $f'(2.0)$.

options.label: C
options.explanation: This is the forward difference: $\frac{f(2.1)-f(2.0)}{0.1}=12.6$.

options.label: D
options.explanation: This is $f(2.1)-f(1.9)=2.4$, but it forgets to divide by the time interval $0.2$.

explanation: From the graph, the function decreases without bound as $x\to 2^-$ and increases without bound as $x\to 2^+$, so the one-sided infinite limits have opposite signs.
title: 1.9-P5

prompt: ["Evaluate $\\lim_{x\\to 3} (2x^2-5x+1)$.","https://xzpjlnkirboevkjzitcx.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/images/questions/b55d71f0-0649-4ca1-ab0e-2bb06e7f286a/1769385327064_njn3p.jpg"]
latex: Evaluate $\lim_{x\to 3} (2x^2-5x+1)$.

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct: direct substitution yields 4.

options.label: B
options.explanation: This comes from arithmetic error.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Incorrect. This might come from an arithmetic error.

options.label: D
options.explanation: This is incorrect due to arithmetic; correct result is 4.

explanation: Polynomials are continuous, so substitute directly: $2(3)^2-5(3)+1=18-15+1=4$. Wait: $18-15+1=4$, so the correct answer is 4.
title: Unit1-UT-Q7

prompt: ["Use the graph provided. What type of discontinuity occurs at $x=1$?","https://xzpjlnkirboevkjzitcx.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/images/questions/b55d71f0-0649-4ca1-ab0e-2bb06e7f286a/1769385336198_cdvo8k.jpg"]
latex: Use the graph provided. What type of discontinuity occurs at $x=1$?

options.label: A
options.explanation: Removable would require the two-sided limit to exist.

options.label: B
options.explanation: Correct: different one-sided limits indicates a jump.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Infinite discontinuity occurs near a vertical asymptote.

options.label: D
options.explanation: The function is not continuous at the point.

explanation: The left-hand and right-hand limits at $x=1$ approach different values (1 and 3), so there is a jump discontinuity.
title: Unit1-UT-Q4

prompt: ["Use the graph provided. What is $\\lim_{x\\to 2} f(x)$?","https://xzpjlnkirboevkjzitcx.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/images/questions/b55d71f0-0649-4ca1-ab0e-2bb06e7f286a/1769385350374_pd2ytk.jpg"]
latex: Use the graph provided. What is $\lim_{x\to 2} f(x)$?

options.label: A
options.explanation: Correct: both sides approach positive infinity.

options.label: B
options.explanation: The graph does not go downward near the asymptote.

options.label: C
options.explanation: It does not approach 0 near $x=2$.

options.label: D
options.explanation: An infinite limit here is described by $\infty$.

explanation: The graph shows a vertical asymptote at $x=2$ and both sides rise without bound, so the limit is $\infty$.
title: Unit1-UT-Q12

prompt: ["Use the graph provided. Which value best matches $\\lim_{x\\to 0} \\frac{\\sin x}{x}$?","https://xzpjlnkirboevkjzitcx.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/images/questions/b55d71f0-0649-4ca1-ab0e-2bb06e7f286a/1769385368818_u0wz7o.jpg"]
latex: Use the graph provided. Which value best matches $\lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\sin x}{x}$?

options.label: A
options.explanation: Near 0 the values approach 1, not -1.

options.label: B
options.explanation: It does not approach 0; it approaches 1.

options.label: C
options.explanation: Correct: the limit is 1.

options.label: D
options.explanation: The limit exists even though the function may be undefined at 0.

explanation: As $x\to 0$, the function $\sin x / x$ approaches 1. This is consistent with the squeeze theorem and the graph trend near the origin.
title: Unit1-UT-Q18
